body:
**Anonymous wrote:**

testcase to illustrate the desired behavior for ticket #594

**paj ([@paj](https://github.com/paj)) wrote:**

I agree we should support this. I did wonder if as a hack you could just set schema to be "database.schema", but in fact this doesn't work due to identifier quoting. 

I think using the "owner" argument is abusing the meaning of that, to the point of being confusing. I wonder if we should add another argument to table, perhaps "database".

I'll have a go at coding this up, but I am going to set the priority to low.

**Changes by paj ([@paj](https://github.com/paj)):**

* added labels: **low priority**
* set **milestone** to "0.4.0"
* changed **assignee** from "ram" to "paj"

**Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)) wrote:**

"owner" is deprecated on Table.  For this, I would want to either have "schema" be sent in as two-token'ed name, i.e. "ownername.schemaname", and have quoting logic that needs them separate to use "split()" to find them when needed.  Alternatively we could support "schema" being represented optionally as a list/tuple of names.  In any case its fine to have the IdentifierPreparer, or MS-SQL's subclass of it, check for this condition.  Around compiler.py there's a lot of calls to preparer.quote(table, table.schema) - its fine to change these into preparer.format_table() calls, or alternatively add a flag to preparer.quote() called "split=True" if we know we're sending in a schema name that might be dot-separated.

**Changes by Michael Bayer ([@zzzeek](https://github.com/zzzeek)):**

* changed **milestone** from "0.4.xx" to "0.5.xx"

**Paul Harrington ([@phrrngtn](https://github.com/phrrngtn)) wrote:**

I believe that this is addressed by the changes in ticket#1341

**Michael Trier ([@empty](https://github.com/empty)) wrote:**

Duplicate of #1341. Closed in 2a962802de28615f5c961b423e1a995b7bd691bc.

**Changes by Michael Trier ([@empty](https://github.com/empty)):**

* added labels: **duplicate**
* changed **milestone** from "0.5.xx" to "0.5.4"
* changed **status** to closed

issue.title: table/schema/owner component formatter for ANSIIdentifierPreparer

labels.name: schema
labels.description: things related to the DDL related objects like Table, Column, CreateIndex, etc.

issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by jek ([@jek](https://github.com/jek))**

From #482:

  [...](...) passing the full table in to has_table() still does not eliminate the complexity that some dialects need to query the schema name and tablename as separate columns, so the format_table() method is not flexible enough. a new method "foramt_schema_and_tablename" or similar should be added to ANSIIdentifierPreparer which returns the two names separately, and is called by the generic create/drop methods in ansisql.py to get the quoted names, which then get passed to has_table [...](...)

This new method could return formatted identifiers for the whole path to a table (#594) as a list, and the dialect can '.'.join() them or use them piecemeal as needed.

issue.title: MySQL Reflection: Support for inter-database Foreign Keys
issue.body:
**Migrated issue, originally created by Anonymous**

Hello everyone,

I haven't worked with MSSQL yet, but I guess this ticket somehow relates to #1341 and #594:
In MySQL you can have Foreign Keys referencing tables of a different database on the same database server. When using reflection, those inter-database FK constraints are being ignored, as they do not match the appropriate constraint regular expression.

I might not grasp every aspect of such inter-database constraints in SA yet, but a change to this regular expression seems to suffice in order for relations to be set up correctly between mapped objects of different databases without specifying primaryjoin arguments or overloading column definitions (to include self-made ForeignKey constraints) on reflected tables.

I have attached a diff to databases/mysql.py.


Best Regards,
Thomas Wiebe

----------------------------------------
Attachments: [mysql.patch](../wiki/imported_issue_attachments/1405/mysql.patch)
